description: From Middle English gobet, from Middle French gobet (“mouthful, piece”), diminutive of gobe. See gober.

entries.meaning: A quantity of liquid, often in a sticky blotch.
A lump or chunk of something, especially of raw meat.
An extract of text, or image (especially a quotation), provided as a context for analysis, discussion, or translation in an examination.

verbs.description: gobbet (third-person singular simple present gobbets, present participle gobbeting, simple past and past participle gobbeted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To splash with small quantities of liquid; to spatter.
(transitive) To swallow greedily; to swallow in gobbets.
